    • Method Detail

      • synchronizedSet

        @Pure
public static def synchronizedSet(set : Set<T>,
                                        mutex : Object) : SynchronizedSet<T>  with <T>
        Description copied from class: Collections3
        Returns a synchronized (thread-safe) set backed by the specified set. In order to guarantee serial access, it is critical that all access to the backing set is accomplished through the returned set.

        It is imperative that the user manually synchronize on the returned set when iterating over it: 

         Set s = Collections.synchronizedSet(new HashSet());
 ...
 synchronized (s) {
 Iterator i = s.iterator(); // Must be in the synchronized block
 while (i.hasNext())
 foo(i.next());
 }
        Failure to follow this advice may result in non-deterministic behavior.

        The returned set will be serializable if the specified set is serializable.

        Type Parameters:
        T - - type of the set element.
        Parameters:
        set - the set to be "wrapped" in a synchronized set.
        mutex - is the mutex to use for synchronizing.
        Returns:
        a synchronized view of the specified set.

      • synchronizedCollection

        @Pure
public static def synchronizedCollection(collection : Collection<T>,
                                               mutex : Object) : SynchronizedCollection<T>  with <T>
        Description copied from class: Collections3
        Returns a synchronized (thread-safe) collection backed by the specified collection. In order to guarantee serial access, it is critical that all access to the backing collection is accomplished through the returned collection.

        It is imperative that the user manually synchronize on the returned collection when iterating over it: 

         Collection c = Collections.synchronizedCollection(myCollection);
 ...
 synchronized (c) {
 Iterator i = c.iterator(); // Must be in the synchronized block
 while (i.hasNext())
 foo(i.next());
 }
        Failure to follow this advice may result in non-deterministic behavior.

        The returned collection does not pass the hashCode and equals operations through to the backing collection, but relies on Object's equals and hashCode methods. This is necessary to preserve the contracts of these operations in the case that the backing collection is a set or a list.

        The returned collection will be serializable if the specified collection is serializable.

        Type Parameters:
        T - - type of the set elements.
        Parameters:
        collection - the collection to be "wrapped" in a synchronized collection.
        mutex - is the mutex to use for synchronizing.
        Returns:
        a synchronized view of the specified collection.

      • unmodifiableSynchronizedSet

        @Pure
public static def unmodifiableSynchronizedSet(elements : Set<T>,
                                                    mutex : Object) : SynchronizedSet<T>  with <T>
        Description copied from class: Collections3
        Returns an immutable synchronized (thread-safe) set backed by the specified set. In order to guarantee serial access, it is critical that all access to the backing set is accomplished through the returned set.

        It is imperative that the user manually synchronize on the returned set when iterating over it: 

         Set s = Collections.synchronizedSet(new HashSet());
 ...
 synchronized (s) {
 Iterator i = s.iterator(); // Must be in the synchronized block
 while (i.hasNext())
 foo(i.next());
 }
        Failure to follow this advice may result in non-deterministic behavior.

        The returned set will be serializable if the specified set is serializable.

        Type Parameters:
        T - - type of the elements in the set.
        Parameters:
        elements - the set to transform as unmodifiable set.
        mutex - is the mutex to use for synchronizing.
        Returns:
        an unmodifiable synchronized set.

      • unmodifiableSynchronizedIterable

        @Pure
public static def unmodifiableSynchronizedIterable(elements : Iterable<T>,
                                                         mutex : Object) : SynchronizedIterable<T>  with <T>
        Description copied from class: Collections3
        Returns an immutable synchronized (thread-safe) iterable backed by the specified iterable. In order to guarantee serial access, it is critical that all access to the backing set is accomplished through the returned set.

        It is imperative that the user manually synchronize on the returned set when iterating over it: 

         Set s = Collections.synchronizedSet(new HashSet());
 ...
 synchronized (s) {
 Iterator i = s.iterator(); // Must be in the synchronized block
 while (i.hasNext())
 foo(i.next());
 }
        Failure to follow this advice may result in non-deterministic behavior.

        The returned set will be serializable if the specified set is serializable.

        Type Parameters:
        T - - type of the elements in the iterable.
        Parameters:
        elements - the set to transform as unmodifiable set.
        mutex - is the mutex to use for synchronizing.
        Returns:
